p: The potential of compounds 136 and 137 isolated from C. odorata twigs and leaves [ 52] for the inhibition of protein tyrosine phosphatase 1B (PTP1B) was evaluated through a bioassay according to Zhang et al. [ 89]. These compounds ( 136 IC 50 = 13.09 µg/mL; 137 IC 50 = 3.93 µg/mL) presented significant PTP1B inhibition potential. PTP1B is an important therapeutic target of some metabolic disorders such as diabetes and obesity, and assays performed by Elchebly et al. [ 90] with PTP1B-deficient mice showed enhanced insulin sensitivity and resistance to diet-induced obesity.
